headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Sharon, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Plum Creek earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. John Hobbs, Vice President of Investor Relations, you m
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Sharon, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Plum Creek earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. John Hobbs, Vice President of Investor Relations, you may begin your conference.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sharon. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Year-End 2010 Conference Call for Plum Creek. I'm John Hobbs, Vice President of Investor Relations for the company. Today, we have on the line Rick Holley, President and CEO; and
componenttext:
Thank you, Sharon. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Year-End 2010 Conference Call for Plum Creek. I'm John Hobbs, Vice President of Investor Relations for the company. Today, we have on the line Rick Holley, President and CEO; and David Lambert, Senior Vice President and CFO. 
This call is open to all investors and members of the media. However, the Q&A portion of the call is intended for the professional investment community only. We ask that other participants please follow up with any questions by calling me at 1 (800) 858-5347. I encourage you to visit our website, www.plumcreek.com. There you will find our press release and supplemental financial statements for the full year and fourth quarter of 2010.
Before we begin, I'd like to take this time to remind everyone that certain of our statements today will be forward-looking, involving known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause actual results or performance to differ from those expressed or implied. These risks and factors are routinely detailed in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Following today's prepared remarks, we'll open up the call for your questions.
Now, I'll turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and happy new year. Despite challenging economic environment with near-record unemployment and a very weak housing market, Plum Creek had a good year in 2010. Performance in our Timber Resource segments, our Manufacturing segment and our no
componenttext:
Good afternoon and happy new year. Despite challenging economic environment with near-record unemployment and a very weak housing market, Plum Creek had a good year in 2010. Performance in our Timber Resource segments, our Manufacturing segment and our non-Timber Resource businesses all improved in 2010., as we were able to take advantage of marketplace anomalies. 
During the first half of the year, unusually wet weather in the South and inventory restocking of both log yards and the finished product supply chain helped boost prices and income in our Timber Resource and Manufacturing businesses. In addition we were able to take advantage of the disruption in medium density fiberboard and plywood markets caused by the Chilean earthquake to incrementally add to our Manufacturing earnings.
In our Real Estate segment, we completed the final phase of our three-year Montana conservation transaction. While total real estate income declined $98 million from 2009, all of the reduction is due to the smaller size of the final phase of the Montana conservation transaction. Income from the final stage was $125 million lower than the phase completed in 2009. We continue to hold our most valuable real estate in such states as Florida and Georgia of the market. We'll patiently wait for the value of these properties to rebound when the overall real estate market recovers.
Throughout 2010, we continue to manage our assets with an eye on long-term value. We invested $71 million in our businesses, using $65 million to replant trees and improve forest productivity, which will increase the future harvest and cash flow from this asset. Given the weak markets and continued depressed prices for our sawlogs, we reduced our sawlog harvest more than 500,000 tons from our initial plans. Although this decision impacted our cash flow and earnings for 2010, it also allows us to plant and harvest these trees in the future and capture significantly more values as markets and prices recover.
We also focused on strengthening our investment-grade balance sheet by refinancing upcoming debt maturities at attractive rates. During the year, we reduced our total debt by nearly $100 million and in November, completed a $575 million 10-year bond offering at 4.7%. We used the proceeds from this attractively priced offering to prepay $213 million of notes maturing in 2011. The average coupon on the notes retired was 7.71%. In addition, we prepaid in full a $250 million term credit agreement scheduled to mature in 2012. The remaining $84 million of 2011 debt maturities will be funded with our line of credit. Both Moody's and S&P reaffirmed our investment-grade credit rating and upgraded our outlook to positive during the course of the year.
We also renewed our line of credit for $600 million at favorable rates, which provides the company with ample liquidity. We continue to manage our portfolio of timberlands, selling some nonstrategic lands at attractive prices and using the proceeds to repurchase our stock at attractive values. During 2010, we sold 24,000 acres that generated marginal cash flow for $32 million. We used the proceeds to repurchase 1.4 million shares of our common stock at 36 37 per share. Over the last five years, we've repurchased $24 million shares or 13% of our shares at compelling values in attractive long-term investment and are saving $40 million annually in dividends in attractive short-term investment.
Importantly, our cash flow from operations was $449 million, which more than covered our annual dividend payment of $272 million. We ended the year in excellent financial shape with $252 million of cash and additional $434 million available under our line of credit. 
David will now review our fourth quarter results and discuss our outlook for 2011. David?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. We reported  fourth quarter earnings of $0.37 per share. This includes an $0.08 per share charge on the early retirement of debt. Excluding this charge, earnings were $0.45 a share and within our guidance range of $0.40 to $0.47.In the Nor
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick. We reported  fourth quarter earnings of $0.37 per share. This includes an $0.08 per share charge on the early retirement of debt. Excluding this charge, earnings were $0.45 a share and within our guidance range of $0.40 to $0.47.
In the Northern Resources segment, we reported a $1 million operating profit, down from the third quarter's $5 million profit. As planned, harvest volumes during the fourth quarter were 13% lower than those of the third quarter. The lower harvest volumes drove most of the decline in operating profit. 
Our average Northern sawlog prices were weaker than we initially expected at about 6% or about $4 per ton from the third quarter. Prices for softwood sawlogs in the Northwest drifted down through November and started recovering in December. Western sawmills have increased production in response to strengthening offshore lumber demand, particularly from China.  Fourth quarter lumber production in the West Coast was up 18% compared to the fourth quarter of 2009.
Additionally, export log volumes to China from West Coast increased significantly. Northern pulpwood prices held steady at $39 per ton during the fourth quarter. Customer demand was good and prices remained attractive. 
Northwest log prices continued to improve in January, driven by higher lumber production aimed at export markets, coupled with growth in export log demand. We expect to export 7% of our Oregon sawlogs to China in the first quarter compared to only nominal volumes in the fourth quarter.
We expect our average Northern segment sawlog prices to increase $3 per ton from the fourth quarter's level. In aggregate, we expect higher sawlog prices, slightly lower pulpwood prices and fairly stable volumes compared to the fourth quarter. For the full year, we expect our Northern sawlog harvest volumes and mix to be similar to 2010, about 4 million tons with 55% sawlogs and 45% pulpwood mix.
Turning to our Southern Resources segment. Our fourth quarter operating profit was $28 million, up $3 million from the third quarter's $25 million profit. The increase in operating profit was primarily a function of higher sawlog harvest volumes. Prices for sawlogs and pulpwood both declined 3% to 4% as favorable logging conditions caused by unseasonably dry weather kept customer mills well supplied across the south. Pulpwood demand from pulp and paper customers strong and pulpwood prices remained attractive by historic standards. We expect Southern lumber production to increase during the first quarter, as a handful of males in our operating areas have reopened or are increasing production. 
However, logging conditions remained favorable across the South, and mills are in relatively good shape from an inventory standpoint. As a result, we expect first quarter sawlog and pulpwood prices to hold at fourth quarter levels. We expect our first quarter harvest will be approximately 200,000 tons lower than the first quarter of last year, as we anticipate there will be better pricing opportunities as the year progresses.
The reductions are split evenly between sawlogs and pulpwood. We expect the overall Southern harvest in 2011 to be similar to 2010's level, about 11.4 million tons. We expect our 2010 Southern harvest mix will be similar to the 2010 mix, roughly 45% sawlogs and 55% pulpwood. 
As mills expand production in 2011, we expect existing contractor capacity may become a gating item that limits log supply. However, Plum Creek is an excellent position to respond to market opportunities when and where they arise, as we have a sawlog base of established contractors. As always, we will continues to adjust our harvest plans in response to market conditions, deferring harvest in weaker markets to protect value and temporarily increasing harvest in attractive markets to capture value.
The Real Estate segment recorded revenue of $155 million and operating profit of $73 million for the fourth quarter. The final phase of the Montana conservation sale contributed $89 million to revenue and $37 million to operating profit. The balance of the fourth quarter revenue and income came from the sale of roughly 16,000 of recreation and higher and better used land at an average price of $2,000 per acre. About 2/3 of the acres sold during the quarter came from lower value regions of the Gulf South and the Lake States. 
Small amounts of strategic land sales also contributed to the quarter's performance, with about 21,000 acres selling at an average price of $1,000 per acre. These lands are almost exclusively lower-productivity properties scattered across the South.
In addition to the final phase of the Montana conservation sale, we completed the sale of 8,200 acres of conservation land at an average value of $1,000 per acre. Individuals and family buyers remain cautious and value-oriented. Rural land markets were a bit better in 2010 than in 2009. And we expect an increase in interest and activity level as the economy continues to recover. We expect 2011 Real Estate segment revenues between $250 million and $300 million. We expect to see a typical seasonal pattern in this segment for the second half of the year stronger than the first half. For the year, we estimate land basis will be approximately 30% of segment revenue.
We expect first quarter Real Estate revenues to be between $50 million and $60 million. We estimate land basis will be approximately 30% of revenue for the first quarter. 
The Manufacturing segment reported a $3 million profit during the fourth quarter, down $4 million from the third quarter's $7 million profit. This is better than we initially expected due to stronger lumber prices. Our average lumber price increased 5% compared to the third quarter, while our lumber sales volumes declined about 7% to typical seasonal decline. Our plywood and MDF prices declined 4% to 5%, while their sales volumes declined seasonally as well, both down about 18%.
As mentioned in our press release, we expect the Manufacturing segment to earn between $15 million and $20 million in 2011, a bit less than 2010. We expect underlying business conditions to improve gradually. But we are not counting on a repeat of the dramatic spring 2010 lumber inventory cycle or the tightness in global MDF markets caused by the Chilean earthquake last year. However, growing domestic demand, combined with incremental export demand, could provide stronger-than-expected lumber prices.
Rick reviewed our fourth quarter refinancing activities earlier. After considering the effects of these transactions, we expect our 2011 third party interest expense to be essentially flat with 2010 to approximately $81 million. Lower Manufacturing segment results should result in a small tax benefit in 2011 of less than $5 million. In all, we expect 2011 income from continuing operations to be between $1.20 and $1.45 per share, with the first quarter results between $0.20 and $0.25 per share. Now I'll turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. We remain cautiously optimistic as we enter 2011. Business conditions appear to be improving, albeit slowly in each of our businesses. Lumber prices have been moving up over the past few months. We believe good production discipline on t
componenttext:
Thank you, David. We remain cautiously optimistic as we enter 2011. Business conditions appear to be improving, albeit slowly in each of our businesses. Lumber prices have been moving up over the past few months. We believe good production discipline on the part of lumber manufacturers, combined with growing export demand, is the primary driver of these improved prices. 
Today, West Coast export log volumes are relatively small. However, they are growing rapidly in excellent long-term growth prospects. 
In 2010, we started to see lumber production, the key driver for sawlogs, begin to recover from its lows. Regional lumber production data shows the relationships between lumber production and sawlog prices. On the West Coast, lumber production was up 33% compared to 2009. These markets also showed the strongest price movement for sawlog, with our average price increasing 18% from 2009. In the U.S. South where lumber production was only slightly above that of 2009, our average sawlog prices increased only about 2%. 
We have planned for 2011 conservatively. We assume a fairly muted housing recovery, with residential construction activity growing from a 590,000 start level of the past year to about 680,000 starts in 2011. We also believe that increasing consumer confidence should lead to improved lumber demand from the repair and remodel sector. 
The earnings outlook that we shared with you today assumes the slow improvement demand over the coming months. However, with modest improvements in domestic demand coupled with growing export demand, we could see a stronger price environment. 
As David outlined, our 2011 harvest plans are very similar in terms of both volume and mix to those of the prior year. We plan to keep the harvest our most valuable sawlogs low. Of course we have the option of bringing more volume to the market, should log values return to attractive levels. And we are in excellent position to benefit for any temporary market dislocations that may occur. 
In our Real Estate segment, we will concentrate on capturing attractive prices for lower value properties, holding our most valuable lands for the future. We will continue to keep a close eye on our costs at the same time. 
We continue to manage the company for long-term value creation. Disciplined investment and improving the growth and yield of our forest remains a top priority. During 2011, we are planning capital expenditures between $75 million and $80 million. Reforestation makes up the bulk of our $35 million maintenance capital. We expect to plant about 60 million trees this year. The remaining capital is discretionary investment, primarily advanced treatments aimed at boosting the productivity of our forests.
Looking at the bigger picture, I remain as enthused about the prospects for Plum Creek and the fundamentals of our Timber business as I ever have been. We have talked about the structural changes that are taking place in North American timber markets, and we are beginning to see some of their impacts today. Certainly the change that has grabbing the most attention over the past six months has been the impact of Chinese demand on the North American lumber and log markets. West Coast log markets are benefiting from the increased competition for logs. We are seeing increased demand for logs, as lumber producers in the region boost production to serve Chinese demand. There's also growing competition from buyers of logs for the export market. Currently, the impact of log markets is region-specific and limited to the West Coast. However, continued export growth has a potential to impact North American markets more broadly. British Columbia has grown its trade relationship with the Chinese, with lumber shipments to China growing sevenfold over the past three years. It is estimated that Chinese exports accounted for 20% of British Columbia's lumber production in the second half of 2010. That's roughly 5% of North American lumber demand.
Disciplined capital allocation remains our top priority. We completed our refinancing activities over the past quarter, are in excellent shape in both terms of our capital structure, liquidity and debt maturity schedule. We continue to evaluate the best uses for the excess cash we generate, searching out the best value outcome for our shareholders. 
Now we'll be glad to take your questions.

componenttext: Yes, at the current time, as you note, 6.8 million acres in total, just less than 1 million acres would be the higher and better use category, about 150,000 acres in the development category. I believe there's still a little over 100,000 in the conservation category. And the balance of roughly 200,000 acres would be in the nonstrategic category. And roughly 5.4 million acres will be left, I think and that would be the core timberlands category.

Are you seeing the spreads between the buyers and the sellers narrow? And are you seeing more opportunities as an acquirer of timberlands as you go into 2011?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Clearly over the long term, we hope to be a net acquirer. But first, there's really nothing of note in the marketplace. There's no supply. And at least, what little transactions we've seen, normally smaller than 50,000 acres, the prices are maybe off 10%
componenttext: Clearly over the long term, we hope to be a net acquirer. But first, there's really nothing of note in the marketplace. There's no supply. And at least, what little transactions we've seen, normally smaller than 50,000 acres, the prices are maybe off 10% to 15%. So it's held to the levels we've talked about over the last year or so. Quite frankly, there's just no supply. And there continues to be a fair amount of demand from institutional buyers for what does come on the market. But we remain, we think a long-term acquirer, because we like the asset and we think we manage it pretty well.

componenttext: Well, that piece of property has been in the market for some time. And I don't know what it traded for. We've not been able to find out. But it's North and East of our properties there. And quite frankly, the markets there are somewhat less developed, the lumber and pulpwood markets in there, so. It's a transaction, at least the property we are very familiar with and quite frankly, had no interest in though we had a large ownership there. So it's probably end up being as reported in the press more of a conservation play as opposed to industrial timberland play.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: We saw a little downdraft through the middle of the quarter. And what we've seen lumber prices firming really for the last four months. So the stronger lumber environment is really somewhat driven by the Chinese demand pull plus disciplined production. It
componenttext: We saw a little downdraft through the middle of the quarter. And what we've seen lumber prices firming really for the last four months. So the stronger lumber environment is really somewhat driven by the Chinese demand pull plus disciplined production. It's really started to take place in the West Coast. And we saw lumber log prices jump up rather in December with strong follow-through in January.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Gail, I think a lot of it has to do with the Chinese lumber demand. And the Chinese are starting to buy lumber from U.S. mill in the West Coast. Virtually everyone of our lumber customers in Oregon is now cutting for the Chinese market. But that really st
componenttext: Gail, I think a lot of it has to do with the Chinese lumber demand. And the Chinese are starting to buy lumber from U.S. mill in the West Coast. Virtually everyone of our lumber customers in Oregon is now cutting for the Chinese market. But that really started kind of in November, December. So obviously for 2010, it was a fairly small volume. But it's picked up smartly, and it should be much higher this year. So that's really what, log prices were down a bit early in the quarter. But that's helped pick up, as David said in December and in through the first quarter.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think most of our customers, probably as we are, somewhat cautiously optimistic. I think the tax bill at year end that was passed by Congress gave people some certainty that brings consumer confidence and some of that, which will certainly help the buil
componenttext: I think most of our customers, probably as we are, somewhat cautiously optimistic. I think the tax bill at year end that was passed by Congress gave people some certainty that brings consumer confidence and some of that, which will certainly help the building side. And I think maybe a more friendly regulatory environment, which was talked about by the President recently, is helping people feel better about investments they're making in their mills and production levels and that sort of thing. So I think people are generally coming in here saying, It's going to get a little better. But our housing starts numbers are still pretty muted. We thought we'd see 750,000 starts in 2010, and we were wrong. We may be even a bit high at 690,000 for this year. It's going to come back very slowly. But we're starting to see some positive momentum for the first time I think in a couple of years.

componenttext: First question is on the Manufacturing segment. It looks like your improvement was a lot more pronounced than many others in the business. When you look at 2009 versus 2010, how would you allocate that between maybe some of the cost cutting you did versus product mix?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's combination. Our mills focus on specialty products compared to normal industry mills. Our lumber mill is a specialty boards facility. Plywood plants all produce high-quality sand at specialty grades and the MDFs as well. So we have been a lit
componenttext: I think it's combination. Our mills focus on specialty products compared to normal industry mills. Our lumber mill is a specialty boards facility. Plywood plants all produce high-quality sand at specialty grades and the MDFs as well. So we have been a little bit more resistant to price declines that some of the commodity producers experienced in the second half of the year. Our results have remained very positive. When we restructured our Lumber business last year, it took out some capacity out of our plywood and MDF businesses. We have these businesses dialed in at a cost structure that's much more efficient. And we think we're going to remain. And these are going to be good cash flow producers this year as well.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011

componenttext: In your guidance that it might be a little down this year that segment, does that does that assume that prices don't, for your grades in particular in geographies, don't really move much from here? Or are you building in a decline or an increase?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's hard to get a big increase off of last year. Last year's pricing, if you look at the data, was quite the roller coaster with generally peaking in April and coming down quite a bit by August. We expect that prices are going to be more stable this year
componenttext: It's hard to get a big increase off of last year. Last year's pricing, if you look at the data, was quite the roller coaster with generally peaking in April and coming down quite a bit by August. We expect that prices are going to be more stable this year. We're going out of the box strong in January with pretty good lumber markets, so we'll see if we can't do better than we think.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Chip, the Chilean earthquake and its dislocation at the global MDF market was very significant. When there was a shortage of MDF, prices, of course supply-demand went up. And we increased production from our MDF plant and generated in that plant alone an
componenttext: Chip, the Chilean earthquake and its dislocation at the global MDF market was very significant. When there was a shortage of MDF, prices, of course supply-demand went up. And we increased production from our MDF plant and generated in that plant alone an extra $5 million in cash flow. So there was that event we don't expect to incur. So we think pricing for all of these is going to do reasonably well this year. But there were some of these anomalies last year that we hope to repeat themselves. Not the earthly of course, but the buildup of lumber prices. But we're certainly not forecasting it right now.

componenttext: It's going to depend on the mix. And when we bring to market, it will be a combination of some higher better used lands, clearly a lot of nonstrategic type lands. And I think a better number is probably in the 175,000, 150,000-acre number. It could be slightly higher than that but it will not be in the 200,000 to 250,000. But really it's going to be mix-related. And again a lot of it is going to be in the lower value areas like again, Mississippi, the Lake States and nonstrategic lands throughout the ownership.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess the first question I had obviously is a nice problem to have, with the increase in Chinese demand for both logs and lumber on the West Coast. But given that historically the Chinese have been so opportunistic in coming in and out of the market, wh
componenttext: I guess the first question I had obviously is a nice problem to have, with the increase in Chinese demand for both logs and lumber on the West Coast. But given that historically the Chinese have been so opportunistic in coming in and out of the market, what makes your customers feel that this could be a sustained trend to perhaps maybe what may be a more volatile trend into the future?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: When I look at Chinese demand, it's been growing quite robustly. And for them, they're only providing about 60% of their supply from internal sources. So they're very dependent on export, on imports to provide that. They are still forecasted to grow their
componenttext: When I look at Chinese demand, it's been growing quite robustly. And for them, they're only providing about 60% of their supply from internal sources. So they're very dependent on export, on imports to provide that. They are still forecasted to grow their wood products production significantly over the next five to 10 years. They will have to be looking to increase their imports of wood fiber. And so I think they have developed some new supply sources over the last two or three years. Part of it is starting to look as a result of the Russian export tax. A part of it is just a fundamentally need for wood fiber if they're getting to keep their growth curve.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: I know there's no guarantees. But from your vantage point, do you think that Pacific Northwest and North America have permanently gained market share, say versus Russia, in terms of shipments to China?
componenttext: I know there's no guarantees. But from your vantage point, do you think that Pacific Northwest and North America have permanently gained market share, say versus Russia, in terms of shipments to China?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Rick. I think that is absolutely correct. I think that the changes we've seen are unlike what we saw from the Chinese a decade or two ago, are permanent. They've put infrastructure in place. They put in grading standards for North American lumber
componenttext: This is Rick. I think that is absolutely correct. I think that the changes we've seen are unlike what we saw from the Chinese a decade or two ago, are permanent. They've put infrastructure in place. They put in grading standards for North American lumber now, which they dearly need. And they've always kind of in and out of the log market. But the change from buying so much lumber from British Columbia and also the West Coast is quite a significant change and made an investment in that business.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: If I go back to our model and I think what you're commenting on during the third quarter reporting season, it looks like your fourth quarter pulpwood production especially in the South was meaningfully higher certainly than we are modeling, I think relati
componenttext: If I go back to our model and I think what you're commenting on during the third quarter reporting season, it looks like your fourth quarter pulpwood production especially in the South was meaningfully higher certainly than we are modeling, I think relative to what you're guiding to. If that is a correct assessment, can you remind us what was behind that? And what that continue into 2011?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our pulpwood harvest is a little bit higher. I think our sawlog harvest was as well. It wasn't really a function of anything specific.
componenttext: Our pulpwood harvest is a little bit higher. I think our sawlog harvest was as well. It wasn't really a function of anything specific.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: I seem to remember it was about 1.6 million that you were forecasting to in the quarter, and you came in close to 1.8 million. So that's what's
componenttext: I seem to remember it was about 1.6 million that you were forecasting to in the quarter, and you came in close to 1.8 million. So that's what's

componenttextpreview: We're about 200,000 tons. And there was no particular reason, other than the markets still remain pretty good and we took the volume to various customers.
componenttext: We're about 200,000 tons. And there was no particular reason, other than the markets still remain pretty good and we took the volume to various customers.

componenttext: We'll hear from Mark Wilde, Deutsche Bank.

componenttext: One is can you guys update us, Rick, on the sort of alternative revenue streams that you've been working off of the lands?

componenttextpreview: As far as our non-Timber Resource business?
componenttext: As far as our non-Timber Resource business?

componenttextpreview: Yes exactly.
componenttext: Yes exactly.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's really a combination of oil and gas revenue that we get from royalties basically from oil and gas leases, and that's the largest piece. We do have some construction materials revenue in there as well. And any results that we have from that segment, o
componenttext: It's really a combination of oil and gas revenue that we get from royalties basically from oil and gas leases, and that's the largest piece. We do have some construction materials revenue in there as well. And any results that we have from that segment, oftentimes you see us actually sell or price in other lease, which there were some of that in 2010.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess what I'm curious about, has that business grown the way you have anticipated going back maybe three or four years ago?
componenttext: I guess what I'm curious about, has that business grown the way you have anticipated going back maybe three or four years ago?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Oh, I think so. That was one of the business, as we continually mentioned to you guys, would probably triple in size over the next five years. And we're still, I think on line to do that. One of the things that slowed it a bit was the revenue from oil and
componenttext: Oh, I think so. That was one of the business, as we continually mentioned to you guys, would probably triple in size over the next five years. And we're still, I think on line to do that. One of the things that slowed it a bit was the revenue from oil and gas, because gas prices are down significantly over the last three years. And that's hurt some of the royalties from that business. But clearly with construction materials, some of the opportunities we have there particularly with limestone for a concrete manufacturer, we've got some mines right now that are processed for being permitted. So when those come online, you'll see a lot more cash flow construction materials. So it's one thing we're quite excited about.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk about sort of regional fallout from either mill closures that have happened? I'm thinking particularly of Missoula and also I know there's this pending new page closure up in Wisconsin and perhaps two or three more at some point on Smurf
componenttext: Can you just talk about sort of regional fallout from either mill closures that have happened? I'm thinking particularly of Missoula and also I know there's this pending new page closure up in Wisconsin and perhaps two or three more at some point on Smurfit?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've been very fortunate. We've spent a lot of time over the last five years in some of these land sales that we've had, these more nonstrategic. We're really in markets where some of these mills existed. But we thought long term, it was probably no
componenttext: Yes, we've been very fortunate. We've spent a lot of time over the last five years in some of these land sales that we've had, these more nonstrategic. We're really in markets where some of these mills existed. But we thought long term, it was probably not a good place to own timberland. And in case of Missoula, we were right. So that large conservation transaction we sold substantial amount of our land down in that Missoula area. And in other parts of the country, we've sold some of Wisconsin, which would be certainly going to new page some of the customers there. So we've really tried to focus on customers who are well capitalized and that we thought that could compete long term. So we are really in pretty good shape. Even the Smurfit mills that we serve are some of the better mills in the system. And we think even with the merger that they're in the process of doing, the sale will remain open to the new buyer.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you just give a sort of the puts and takes as you think about sort of timber supply and timber demand over the next five or 10 years? Because it seems like that the depth of this downturn has probably more timber on the stump, more inventory on the st
componenttext: Can you just give a sort of the puts and takes as you think about sort of timber supply and timber demand over the next five or 10 years? Because it seems like that the depth of this downturn has probably more timber on the stump, more inventory on the stump than any of us would have imagined five years ago. At the same time, you've got this mountain beetle issue up in the Interior B.C. And now we've got this pickup in Chinese demand. So how do you sort all of those out?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the one thing we need to keep in mind, when you look at timberland ownership, a lot of these companies like Plum Creek or Rainer Palace, whoever it is, deferred some harvest. We represent such a small portion of total timber supply. If you look at t
componenttext: Well, the one thing we need to keep in mind, when you look at timberland ownership, a lot of these companies like Plum Creek or Rainer Palace, whoever it is, deferred some harvest. We represent such a small portion of total timber supply. If you look at the U.S. South, 80% of wood fiber there is owned by small non-industrials who are not necessarily acting the same way. So there's not as much inventory on the sidelines as one might think that's not been cut. But setting that aside, you make a really good point. Because on the demand side, with the whole situation in B.C. and we're starting to see the impact of that, with B.C. increasingly serving the Chinese market, with the Chinese on the West Coast market, so there's new demand sources and there's going to be a shrinkage of supply out of B.C., which is going to require that more the lumber production will come from the United States especially as markets recover. And the other thing that you heard us talk about is just whole energy opportunity, be it biomass or renewable energy. And it's a little slow on the take here. But eventually, it's going to have an impact, we believe on the marketplace and that will impact pulpwood. And at the same time, and David mentioned in his comments, is really we think one of the governor on this engine of timber supply is contracted capacity. And I can't even overstate how significant of an impact that's going to have as this market recovers. If you look at production being down 20% to 30% U.S. South that means 20% to 30% of the contractors have been out of business for two or three years. And many of them will not be back. So as we see demand improve, it's going to be very hard to get that product back to market. And that's the governor on that engine. That's why we believe we'll see more price impact from a recovery than might expect otherwise.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from Steven Chercover, D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: Your next question will come from Steven Chercover, D.A. Davidson.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you gauge how big you think the Chinese market can ultimately be? I mean it's up sevenfold over the last couple of years. But is it still fairly embryonic, you think?
componenttext: Can you gauge how big you think the Chinese market can ultimately be? I mean it's up sevenfold over the last couple of years. But is it still fairly embryonic, you think?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's up sevenfold from a very small starting point. But I think it's ...
componenttext: It's up sevenfold from a very small starting point. But I think it's ...

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: This year, we expect them to import about 2 billion board feet of lumber from Canada and the United States. Over 90% of that is coming from Canada. If you look at the run rate just in kind of the fourth quarter, they're kind of importing at a 3 billion bo
componenttext: This year, we expect them to import about 2 billion board feet of lumber from Canada and the United States. Over 90% of that is coming from Canada. If you look at the run rate just in kind of the fourth quarter, they're kind of importing at a 3 billion board foot level. So they're already greater than 5% of what North American production capacity is at this point. Their growth trends, which show them needing to almost grow by 50% over the next five to six years their total level of imports, and so we think that this could be a very big opportunity. I'm somewhat surprised that it's manifested itself this quickly and rapidly. And it's starting to have that impact. You have to remember that sawmills here in North America are running closer to 60% of capacity. Housing's still awful. What I want to do is fast-forward in my mind five years when we don't have the timber supply out of British Columbia, mills are running at full or capacity, the U.S. dollar remains relatively weak compared to where it was in the last cycle, I can see much higher lumber prices and very vibrant log markets in that scenario.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: The U.S. is still selling primarily logs. Are you directly participating or just enjoying the benefit of higher prices in the region?
componenttext: The U.S. is still selling primarily logs. Are you directly participating or just enjoying the benefit of higher prices in the region?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Up till now, we have not been selling the volume to China, or it wasn't really that measurable. But as I indicated in my comments, we expect to sell 7% of our first quarter production to China off of our lands in our West Coast region in the first quarter
componenttext: Up till now, we have not been selling the volume to China, or it wasn't really that measurable. But as I indicated in my comments, we expect to sell 7% of our first quarter production to China off of our lands in our West Coast region in the first quarter. So as Rick indicated, we're just really starting to see dramatic change in the market in the last couple of months.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Steve, we're not selling any lumber directly to China. Virtually every lumber customer we have in the state of Oregon is now cutting for the Chinese markets. So we are indirectly impacted even with our logs in the domestic market.
componenttext: And Steve, we're not selling any lumber directly to China. Virtually every lumber customer we have in the state of Oregon is now cutting for the Chinese markets. So we are indirectly impacted even with our logs in the domestic market.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Over the years, you've divested quite a number of sawmills in Southern states and you've closed facilities in Montana. Would you ever actually contemplate having a building, but buying a coastal mill so as to capture additional value as you start to expor
componenttext: Over the years, you've divested quite a number of sawmills in Southern states and you've closed facilities in Montana. Would you ever actually contemplate having a building, but buying a coastal mill so as to capture additional value as you start to export the Chinese market?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I think rather somebody else hold the coastal sawmills and we'll just provide logs to them.
componenttext: No, I think rather somebody else hold the coastal sawmills and we'll just provide logs to them.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011

componenttext: Your next question will come from Joshua Barber, Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: All your comments about China so far, have you seen any demand for the Chinese actually buying some U.S. timberlands as opposed to just the lumber logs so far?
componenttext: All your comments about China so far, have you seen any demand for the Chinese actually buying some U.S. timberlands as opposed to just the lumber logs so far?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't. And it's a question we asked ourselves a number of years ago. And I think there was a hesitancy on behalf of even some of the sovereign funds in China doing that and how we look domestically here. So we've not seen them at all interested i
componenttext: No, we haven't. And it's a question we asked ourselves a number of years ago. And I think there was a hesitancy on behalf of even some of the sovereign funds in China doing that and how we look domestically here. So we've not seen them at all interested in buying timberlands here. Not to say that it wouldn't happen in the future, but so far it's not.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Would you say most of the momentum that we've had so far in the log and lumber prices in December and January is driven by China? Or do you think some of that has to do with some people being a little bit more optimistic about spring building season?
componenttext: Would you say most of the momentum that we've had so far in the log and lumber prices in December and January is driven by China? Or do you think some of that has to do with some people being a little bit more optimistic about spring building season?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Probably more China than the spring building season, but really some of both, probably 2/3-1/3.
componenttext: Probably more China than the spring building season, but really some of both, probably 2/3-1/3.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you can see a little bit of it manifest at the end that you have higher lumber values coming out of British Columbia and the West Coast, and they've shown that where southern lumber values haven't participated as much. And so it is a little bit of
componenttext: I think you can see a little bit of it manifest at the end that you have higher lumber values coming out of British Columbia and the West Coast, and they've shown that where southern lumber values haven't participated as much. And so it is a little bit of a regional phenomena, as you see tightness in the overall markets improve than we had expected to spread at the South.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Have you seen any, I guess, improvement in the quality of the logs that they're looking for now? Or are they still sticking to the number two to number four grade lumber?
componenttext: Have you seen any, I guess, improvement in the quality of the logs that they're looking for now? Or are they still sticking to the number two to number four grade lumber?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, they generally buy the lower grade log and lower grade lumber. That's primarily what they're buying out of British Columbia. So it's the lower grade lumber products that a lot of it is being manufactured from beetle timber. They use it for and that s
componenttext: Yes, they generally buy the lower grade log and lower grade lumber. That's primarily what they're buying out of British Columbia. So it's the lower grade lumber products that a lot of it is being manufactured from beetle timber. They use it for and that sort of application, not 2x4 homebuilding. Hopefully that will come in the future.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: The Russian wood has declined from where it was back in 2007 with the tax. At this point, I think we would expect Russian imports at large to be stable to rising. So this is really handling the net growth in the market following that tax. So compared to 2
componenttext: The Russian wood has declined from where it was back in 2007 with the tax. At this point, I think we would expect Russian imports at large to be stable to rising. So this is really handling the net growth in the market following that tax. So compared to 2007, yes, we have replaced Russian wood. And so has New Zealand and other countries as well.

componenttext: One silver lining in this down economic environment is the willingness of a lot of the jurisdictions to work with you on entitlements. componenttext: I was hoping you could talk a little bit about the dividend outlook. Is there a certain coverage ratio that you guys would like to see before you get comfortable with an increase? Or is it more based on kind of a sustained improvement in sawlog pricing and harvest levels?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's more of a case, as we said on the call comments, we more than covered the dividend in 2010 and will in 2011 as well. But as we continue to see the core business, that being in our Timber Resource business improve this year and next, I think t
componenttext: I think it's more of a case, as we said on the call comments, we more than covered the dividend in 2010 and will in 2011 as well. But as we continue to see the core business, that being in our Timber Resource business improve this year and next, I think then you can look to increasing the dividend. We want to make sure that any improvement, we can sustain, because you hate to go forward and never come back. But clearly, we're focused as business conditions improve to grow the dividend.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: You indicated, I believe, that nearly every customer in the Northwest was sending at least some wood offshore. I'm curious if you've seen any evidence in the U.S. South of interest in Chinese demand for U.S. South customers?
componenttext: You indicated, I believe, that nearly every customer in the Northwest was sending at least some wood offshore. I'm curious if you've seen any evidence in the U.S. South of interest in Chinese demand for U.S. South customers?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: We haven't seen that as of yet. I think the Chinese, they're comfortable with kind of Douglas fir and the species. And that's why they're focused their activities here in the Northwest thus far. But I think to the extent that demand continues to grow and
componenttext: We haven't seen that as of yet. I think the Chinese, they're comfortable with kind of Douglas fir and the species. And that's why they're focused their activities here in the Northwest thus far. But I think to the extent that demand continues to grow and it can't be served by this market, they very well will look there. And the other good thing is to the extent that they are buying a lot of product in this part of the region, of the country from B.C, as demand improves, that demand will have to be filled by the U.S. South. So they will participate indirectly anyway.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Secondary story, Pete, but exports have been growing to din many regions and not just to China. U.S. exports are going to be up 50% lumber this year. And China just represents a small portion of that growth. So with the more competitive dollar, the indust
componenttext: Secondary story, Pete, but exports have been growing to din many regions and not just to China. U.S. exports are going to be up 50% lumber this year. And China just represents a small portion of that growth. So with the more competitive dollar, the industry has really positioned itself to be much more competitive globally.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: What we have seen is a strong relationship between lumber production and sawlogs over time. So as greater demand for sawmills grow then we see it flow through into the log values, you do need to have a certain level of lumber prices to allow the mills to
componenttext: What we have seen is a strong relationship between lumber production and sawlogs over time. So as greater demand for sawmills grow then we see it flow through into the log values, you do need to have a certain level of lumber prices to allow the mills to pay. And it's been our experience over time that most of the value flows through the land owner in the form of the trees. And that's one of the strategic perspective why we've always positioned ourselves more as a land and timber company as opposed to a mill converter.

componenttext: That $40 million to $45 million, there's probably around $3 million that will go into maintenance capital in our sawmills and lumber and plywood and MDF. But the balance, the return for our silvicultural investment is kind of 15% IRR or higher for us to make the investment. And we go through an investment analysis in every one of those silvicultural expenditures.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think with respect to well-managed commercial timberlands, you are seeing improvement. But I think Rick, in his comments earlier, talked about how 80% of the timberland is owned by small non-industrials. So there's a portion of the market that's during
componenttext: I think with respect to well-managed commercial timberlands, you are seeing improvement. But I think Rick, in his comments earlier, talked about how 80% of the timberland is owned by small non-industrials. So there's a portion of the market that's during this intensive silviculture starting with better seedling quality in the fertilization and competition control. So the yields off the lands today are better than what they were for 20 years ago. And we're starting to see that in our forests. And that's certainly part of the growth prospects why we see our harvest growing to 20 million tons in the future from the 15.5 million tons we're at today. And that even includes downsizing our portfolio with the disposition of real estate. So we're getting about 1.5% compound annual improvement in productivity.

componenttext: I think, John, what we had last year, we don't really have -- the harvest in the Northern segment, we don't really mind the coldness. They worked well. I think what we saw last year, the U.S. South had a very wet spring and mills were tied on inventories. And we got some really strong pulpwood values early in the year. And you saw pulpwood values decline as the year went through. It wasn't really from lack of demand. It was just that we didn't have the same difficult harvest conditions. Right now, we are having a rather dry fall and winter down South. And so we really don't have that difficult logging conditions, and it's impacting pricing a little bit. We don't sense any risk into our harvest outlook with respect to weather at this point.

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Zerona, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Plum Creek Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. John Hobbs, Vice President of Investor Relations, you may begin your conference.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Zerona. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Year-End 2010 Conference Call for Plum Creek. I'm John Hobbs, Vice President of Investor Relations for the company. Today, we have on the line Rick Holley, President and CEO; and
componenttext:
Thank you, Zerona. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Year-End 2010 Conference Call for Plum Creek. I'm John Hobbs, Vice President of Investor Relations for the company. Today, we have on the line Rick Holley, President and CEO; and David Lambert, Senior Vice President and CFO. 
This call is open to all investors and members of the media. However, the Q&A portion of the call is intended for the professional investment community only. We ask that other participants please follow up with any questions by calling me at 1 (800) 858-5347. I encourage you to visit our website, www.plumcreek.com. There you will find our press release and supplemental financial statements for the full year and fourth quarter of 2010.
Before we begin, I'd like to take this time to remind everyone that certain of our statements today will be forward-looking, involving known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause actual results or performance to differ from those expressed or implied. These risks and factors are routinely detailed in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Following today's prepared remarks, we'll open up the call for your questions.
Now, I'll turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and Happy New Year. Despite a challenging economic environment, with near-record unemployment and a very weak housing market, Plum Creek had a good year in 2010. Performance in our timber resource segments, our Manufacturing segment and our
componenttext:
Good afternoon and Happy New Year. Despite a challenging economic environment, with near-record unemployment and a very weak housing market, Plum Creek had a good year in 2010. Performance in our timber resource segments, our Manufacturing segment and our non-timber resource businesses all improved in 2010, as we were able to take advantage of marketplace anomalies. 
During the first half of the year, unusually wet weather in the South and inventory restocking of both log yards and the finished products supply chain helped boost prices and income in our timber resource and Manufacturing businesses. In addition, we were able to take advantage of the disruption in medium density fiberboard and plywood markets caused by the Chilean earthquake to incrementally add to our Manufacturing earnings.
In our Real Estate segment, we completed the final phase of our three-year Montana conservation transaction. While total real estate income declined $98 million from 2009, all of the reduction is due to the smaller size of the final phase of the Montana conservation transaction. Income from the final phase was $125 million lower than the phase completed in 2009. We continue to hold our most valuable real estate, in such states as Florida and Georgia, off the market. We'll patiently wait for the value of these properties to rebound when the overall real estate market recovers.
Throughout 2010, we continued to manage our assets with an eye on long-term value. We invested $71 million in our businesses, using $65 million to replant trees and improve forest productivity, which will increase the future harvest and cash flow from this asset. Given the weak markets and continued depressed prices for our sawlogs, we reduced our sawlog harvest more than 500,000 tons from our initial plans. Although this decision impacted our cash flow and earnings for 2010, it also allows us to plant, we're going to harvest these trees in the future and capture significantly more values as markets and prices recover.
We're also focused on strengthening our investment-grade balance sheet by refinancing upcoming debt maturities at attractive rates. During the year, we reduced our total debt by nearly $100 million, and in November, completed a $575 million 10-year bond offering at 4.7%. We used the proceeds from this attractively priced offering to prepay $213 million of notes maturing in 2011. The average coupon on the notes retired was 7.71%. In addition, we prepaid in full a $250 million term credit agreement scheduled to mature in 2012. The remaining $94 million of 2011 debt maturities will be funded with our line of credit. Both Moody's and S&P reaffirmed our investment-grade credit rating and upgraded our outlook to positive during the course of the year.
We also renewed our line of credit for $600 million at favorable rates, which provides the company with ample liquidity. We continue to manage our portfolio of timberlands, selling some nonstrategic lands at attractive prices and using the proceeds to repurchase our stock at attractive values. During 2010, we sold 24,000 acres, that generated marginal cash flow, for $32 million. We used the proceeds to repurchase 1.4 million shares of our common stock at $36.37 per share. Over the last five years, we've repurchased $24 million shares, or 13% of our shares, at compelling values in attractive long-term investment and are saving $40 million annually in dividends in attractive short-term investment.
Importantly, our cash flow from operations was $449 million, which more than covered our annual dividend payment of $272 million. We ended the year in excellent financial shape with $252 million of cash, an additional $434 million available under our line of credit. 
David will now review our fourth quarter results and discuss our outlook for 2011. David?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. We reported  fourth quarter earnings of $0.37 per share. This includes an $0.08 per share charge on the early retirement of debt. Excluding this charge, earnings were $0.45 a share and within our guidance range of $0.40 to $0.47.In the Nor
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick. We reported  fourth quarter earnings of $0.37 per share. This includes an $0.08 per share charge on the early retirement of debt. Excluding this charge, earnings were $0.45 a share and within our guidance range of $0.40 to $0.47.
In the Northern Resources segment, we reported a $1 million operating profit, down from the third quarter's $5 million profit. As planned, harvest volumes during the fourth quarter were 13% lower than those of the third quarter. The lower harvest volumes drove most of the decline in operating profit. 
Our average Northern sawlog prices were weaker than we initially expected, up about 6%, or about $4 per ton from the third quarter. Prices for softwood sawlogs in the Northwest drifted down through November and started recovering in December. Western sawmills have increased production in response to strengthening offshore lumber demand, particularly from China.  Fourth quarter lumber production in the West Coast was up 18% compared to the fourth quarter of 2009.
Additionally, export log volumes to China from West Coast ports increased significantly. Northern pulpwood prices held steady at $39 per ton during the fourth quarter. Customer demand was good and prices remained attractive. 
Northwest log prices continued to improve in January, driven by higher lumber production aimed at export markets, coupled with growth in export log demand. We expect to export 7% of our Oregon sawlogs to China in the first quarter, compared to only nominal volumes in the fourth quarter.
We expect our average Northern segment sawlog prices to increase $3 per ton from the fourth quarter's level. In aggregate, we expect higher sawlog prices, slightly lower pulpwood prices and fairly stable volumes compared to the fourth quarter. For the full year, we expect our northern sawlog harvest volumes and mix to be similar to 2010, about 4 million tons, with 55% sawlogs and 45% pulpwood mix.
Turning to our Southern Resource segment. Our fourth quarter operating profit was $28 million, up $3 million from the third quarter's $25 million profit. The increase in operating profit was primarily a function of higher sawlog harvest volumes. Prices for sawlogs and pulpwood both declined 3% to 4% as favorable logging conditions, caused by unseasonably dry weather, kept customer mills well-supplied across the south. Pulpwood demand from pulp and paper customers remained strong, and pulpwood prices remained attractive by historic standards. We expect southern lumber production to increase during the first quarter, as a handful of mills in our operating areas have reopened or are increasing production. 
However, logging conditions remained favorable across the South, and mills are in relatively good shape from an inventory standpoint. As a result, we expect first quarter southern sawlog and pulpwood prices to hold at fourth quarter levels. We expect our first quarter harvest will be approximately 200,000 tons lower than the first quarter of last year, as we anticipate there will be better pricing opportunities as the year progresses.
The reductions are split evenly between sawlogs and pulpwood. We expect the overall southern harvest in 2011 to be similar to 2010's level, about 11.4 million tons. We expect our 2010 southern harvest mix will be similar to the 2010 mix, roughly 45% sawlogs and 55% pulpwood. 
As mills expand production in 2011, we expect existing contractor capacity may become a gating item that limits log supplies. However, Plum Creek is an excellent position to respond to market opportunities when and where they arise, as we have a solid base of established contractors. As always, we will continue to adjust our harvest plans in response to market conditions, deferring harvest in weaker markets to protect value and temporarily increasing harvest in attractive markets to capture value.
The Real Estate segment recorded revenue of $155 million and operating profit of $73 million for the fourth quarter. The final phase of the Montana conservation sale contributed $89 million to revenue and $37 million to operating profit. The balance of the fourth quarter revenue and income came from the sale of roughly 16,000 of recreation and higher and better use land at an average price of $2,000 per acre. About 2/3 of the acres sold during the quarter came from lower-value regions of the Gulf South and the Lake States. 
Small nonstrategic land sales also contributed to the quarter's performance, with about 21,000 acres selling at an average price of $1,000 per acre. These lands are almost exclusively lower-productivity properties scattered across the South.
In addition to the final phase of the Montana conservation sale, we completed the sale of 8,200 acres of conservation land at an average value of $1,000 per acre. Individuals and family buyers remain cautious and value-oriented. Rural land markets were a bit better in 2010 than in 2009, and we expect an increase in interest and activity levels as the economy continues to recover. We expect 2011 Real Estate segment revenues between $250 million and $300 million. We expect to see a typical seasonal pattern in this segment, with the second half of the year stronger than the first half. For the year, we estimate land bases will be approximately 30% of segment revenue.
We expect first quarter Real Estate revenues to be between $50 million and $60 million. We estimate land bases will be approximately 30% of revenue for the first quarter. 
The Manufacturing segment reported a $3 million profit during the fourth quarter, down $4 million from the third quarter's $7 million profit. This was better than we initially expected, due to stronger lumber prices. Our average lumber price increased 5% compared to the third quarter, while our lumber sales volumes declined about 7% to typical seasonal decline. Our plywood and MDF prices declined 4% to 5%, while their sales volumes declined seasonally as well, both down about 18%.
As mentioned in our press release, we expect the Manufacturing segment to earn between $15 million and $20 million in 2011, a bit less than 2010. We expect underlying business conditions to improve gradually, but we are not counting on a repeat of the dramatic spring 2010 lumber inventory cycle or the tightness in global MDF markets caused by the Chilean earthquake last year. However, growing domestic demand, combined with incremental export demand, could provide stronger-than-expected lumber prices.
Rick reviewed our fourth quarter refinancing activities earlier. After considering the effect of these transactions, we expect our 2011 third party interest expense to be essentially flat with 2010 to approximately $81 million. Lower Manufacturing segment results should result in a small tax benefit in 2011, less than $5 million. In all, we expect 2011 income from continuing operations to be between $1.20 and $1.45 per share, with the first quarter results between $0.20 and $0.25 per share. Now I'll turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. We remain cautiously optimistic as we enter 2011. Business conditions appear to be improving, albeit slowly, in each of our businesses. Lumber prices have been moving up over the past few months. We believe good production discipline on
componenttext:
Thank you, David. We remain cautiously optimistic as we enter 2011. Business conditions appear to be improving, albeit slowly, in each of our businesses. Lumber prices have been moving up over the past few months. We believe good production discipline on the part of lumber manufacturers, combined with growing export demand, is the primary driver of these improved prices. 
Today, West Coast export log volumes are relatively small. However, they are growing rapidly in excellent long-term growth prospects. 
In 2010, we started to see lumber production, the key driver for sawlogs, begin to recover from its lows. Regional lumber production data shows the relationship between lumber production and sawlog prices. On the West Coast, lumber production was up 33% compared to 2009. These markets also showed the strongest price movement for sawlogs, with our average price increasing 18% from 2009. In the U.S. South, where lumber production was only slightly above that of 2009, our average sawlog prices increased only about 2%. 
We have planned for 2011 conservatively. We assume a fairly muted housing recovery, with residential construction activity growing from a 590,000 start level of the past year to about 680,000 starts in 2011. We also believe that increasing consumer confidence should lead to improved lumber demand from the repair and remodel sector. 
The earnings outlook that we shared with you today assumes this slow improvement demand over the coming months. However, with modest improvements in domestic demand, coupled with growing export demand, we could see a stronger price environment. 
As David outlined, our 2011 harvest plans are very similar, in terms of both volume and mix, to those of the prior year. We plan to keep the harvest of our most valuable sawlogs low. Of course, we have the option of bringing more volume to the market, should log values return to attractive levels. And we are in excellent position to benefit from any temporary market dislocations that may occur. 
In our Real Estate segment, we will concentrate on capturing attractive prices for lower-value properties, holding our most valuable lands for the future. We will continue to keep a close eye on our costs at the same time. 
We continue to manage the company for long-term value creation. Disciplined investment and improving the growth and yield of our forests remains a top priority. During 2011, we are planning capital expenditures between $75 million and $80 million. Reforestation makes up the bulk of our $35 million of maintenance capital. We expect to plant about 60 million trees this year. The remaining capital is discretionary investment, primarily advanced silviculture treatments aimed at boosting the productivity of our forests.
Looking at the bigger picture, I remain as enthused about the prospects for Plum Creek and the fundamentals of the timber business as I ever have been. We have talked about the structural changes that are taking place in North American timber markets, and we are beginning to see some of their impacts today. Certainly, the change that has grabbed the most attention over the past six months has been the impact of Chinese demand on the North American lumber and log markets. West Coast log markets are benefiting from the increased competition for logs. We are seeing increased demand for logs, as lumber producers in the region boost production to serve Chinese demand. There's also growing competition from buyers of logs for the export market. Currently, the impact on log markets is region-specific and limited to the West Coast. However, continued export growth has the potential to impact North American markets more broadly. British Columbia has grown its trade relationship with the Chinese, with lumber shipments to China growing sevenfold over the past three years. It is estimated that Chinese exports accounted for 20% of British Columbia's lumber production in the second half of 2010. That's roughly 5% of North American lumber demand.
Disciplined capital allocation remains our top priority. We completed our refinancing activities over the past quarter, are in an excellent shape in both terms of our capital structure, liquidity and debt maturity schedules. We continue to evaluate the best uses for the excess cash we generate, searching out the best-value outcome for our shareholders. 
Now we'll be glad to take your questions.

componenttext: Yes, at the current time, as you know, it's 6.8 million acres in total. Just less than 1 million acres would be in the higher and better use category. About 150,000 acres in the development category I believe there's still a little over 100,000 in the conservation category and the balance of roughly 200,000 acres would be in the nonstrategic category. And roughly 5.4 million acres would be what's left, I think, and it would be in the core timberland category.

componenttext: Can you talk about what you're seeing in the markets right now for timberland? You mentioned you bought back some of your stock in 2010. Are you seeing the spreads between the buyers and the sellers narrow? And are you seeing more opportunities as an acquirer of timberlands, as you go into 2011?

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, over the long term, we hope to be a net acquirer. But first, there's really nothing of note in the marketplace. There's no supply. And lease, what little transactions we've seen, normally smaller than 50,000 acres, the prices are maybe off
componenttext: Well, clearly, over the long term, we hope to be a net acquirer. But first, there's really nothing of note in the marketplace. There's no supply. And lease, what little transactions we've seen, normally smaller than 50,000 acres, the prices are maybe off 10% to 15%. So it kind of held to the levels we've talked about over the last year or so. But quite frankly, there is just no supply, and there continues to be a fair amount of demand from institutional buyers for what does come on the market. But we remain, we think a long-term acquirer, because we like the asset and we think we manage it pretty well.

componenttext: Well, that piece of property has been on the market for some time, and I don't know what it traded for. We have not been able to find out. But it's a transaction, or at least a property we are very familiar with and, quite frankly, had no interest, even though we have a large ownership there. So it's probably end up being, as I think was reported in the press, more of a conservation play, as opposed to an industrial timberland play.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: We saw a little downdraft through the middle of the quarter. And what we've seen, lumber prices firming really for the last four months. So the stronger lumber environment, it's really somewhat driven by the Chinese demand pull plus disciplined production
componenttext: We saw a little downdraft through the middle of the quarter. And what we've seen, lumber prices firming really for the last four months. So the stronger lumber environment, it's really somewhat driven by the Chinese demand pull plus disciplined production. It's really started to take place in the West Coast. And we saw log prices jump up rather smartly in December, with strong follow-through in January.

headline: Plum Creek Timber Co. Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: So Gail, I think a lot of it has to do with the Chinese lumber demand. And the Chinese are starting to buy lumber from U.S. mills on the West Coast. Virtually every one of our lumber customers in Oregon is now cutting for the Chinese market. But that real
componenttext: So Gail, I think a lot of it has to do with the Chinese lumber demand. And the Chinese are starting to buy lumber from U.S. mills on the West Coast. Virtually every one of our lumber customers in Oregon is now cutting for the Chinese market. But that really started kind of in November, December. So obviously for 2010, it was a fairly small volume, but it's picked up smartly, and it should be much higher this year. So that's really what -- log prices were down a bit early in the quarter, but that's what helped them pick up, as David said, in December and in through the first quarter.
